content: The Act may be cited as the "Attorney-Client Privilege Protection Act of 2008". Congress finds that justice is served when all parties in litigation have experienced counsel, protecting attorney-client privileged communications promotes compliance with the law, and the ability of organizations to conduct internal investigations is improved with clarity on privileged communications. The attorney-client privilege enhances organizations' compliance programs and internal investigations by providing clarity and consistency. Prosecutors and government officials can effectively conduct their work while respecting these protections and individuals' rights. Congress acknowledges the importance of law enforcement in investigations. Despite the availability of investigative tools that do not impact attorney-client privilege, the Department of Justice and other agencies have implemented policies that undermine this protection. Congress recognized the importance of law enforcement in investigations by banning demands for privileged materials in the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. The Department of Justice and other agencies are implementing policies that undermine the adversarial system of justice by encouraging organizations to waive attorney-client privilege and work product protections to avoid indictment. This encroaches on constitutional rights and can have devastating consequences on organizations. The purpose of this Act is to set clear limits on agencies to protect attorney-client privilege and work product doctrine from being used to conceal wrongdoing or evade the law. In General, Chapter 201 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section 3014 on the preservation of fundamental legal protections and rights in investigations and enforcement matters regarding organizations. The section defines attorney-client privilege as governed by common law principles and Federal Rules of Evidence. The term 'attorney work product' refers to materials prepared by or at the direction of an attorney in anticipation of litigation, containing their mental impressions, conclusions, opinions, or legal theories. The term 'organization' excludes a continuing criminal enterprise as defined in the Controlled Substances Act.
